Citation.Paragraph: Additions and corrections to previous parts (Bolton, 1976
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
This is the third part of a series of papers covering the taxonomy of the ant tribe
Tetramoriini Part one (Bolton, 1976
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: defined the tribe and its constituent genera and reviewed or revised the smaller genera. The second part (Bolton, 1977
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: The Malagasy fauna consists of 36 known species and has not previously been monographed, whilst the New World has 11 species, four of which are endemic and seven of which are introduced. The New World forms were previously examined by M. R. Smith (1938
Citation.Name: M. R. Smith

Citation.Paragraph: with additional later information from Creighton (1950
Citation.Name: Creighton

Citation.Paragraph: and Brown (1957
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph: Tetramorium Tetramorium Mayr, 1855
Citation.Name: Mayr

Citation.Paragraph:
423. Type-species:
Formica caespitum Formica caespitum L. , 1758: 581, by subsequent designation of Girard, 1879
Citation.Name: Girard

Citation.Paragraph:
385 [as subgenus of
Tetramorium Tetramorium ]. Type-species:
Tetramorium kelleri Tetramorium {Xiphomyrmex) kelleri Forel , loc. cit.; by subsequent designation of Wheeler, 1911
Citation.Name: Wheeler

Citation.Paragraph: 175. [Synonymy by Bolton, 1976
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
For a full statement of the generic synonymy of
Tetramorium Tetramorium (=
Tetrogmus Tetrogmus Roger, =
Xiphomyrmex Xiphomyrmex Forel, =
Atopula Atopula Emery, =
Macromischoides Macromischoides Wheeler, =
Sulcomyrmex Sulcomyrmex Kratochvil, =
Lobomyrmex Lobomyrmex Kratochvil) see Bolton, 1976
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: A more complete definition of the genus has been given previously (Bolton, 1976
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
In the regions now under consideration
Tetramorium Tetramorium is the only tetramoriine genus with endemic species, although tramp-species of the genus
Triglyphothrix Triglyphothrix Forel are known to occur (certainly
Triglyphothrix lanuginosa Tr. lanuginosa (Mayr) and very probably
Triglyphothrix kheperra Tr. kheperra Bolton ). These are distinguished from
Tetramorium Tetramorium by their possession of numerous branched hairs, bifid or trifid, on all surfaces of the body. Finally, the parasitic genus
Anergates Anergates Forel, whose host is
Tetramorium caespitum Tetramorium caespitum (L.) , is known from New Jersey, U. S. A., but this is hardly likely to be confused with
Tetramorium Tetramorium as it lacks a worker caste, has an apterous, pupoidal male and is morphologically very distinct (see Bolton, 1976
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
The endemic species fall into six species-groups and it is interesting to note that in Madagascar, as in Australia, forms with 11 - merous antennae greatly outnumber those in which the antennae are 12 - merous. Thus, of Madagascar's 29 endemics only 4 species have 12 - segmented antennae. (In Australia, of 17 known endemic species only 2 have 12 - segmented antennae, and in the New World no endemic forms with 12 segments are known.) In the main range of
Tetramorium Tetramorium , through the Palaearctic, Ethiopian, Oriental and Indo-Australian regions, the reverse is true: the Palaearctic has no endemic species with 11 - merous antennae; the Ethiopian has 22 out of about 150 known species; the Oriental 7 out of 29 and the Indo-Australian 10 out of 46. In the first part of this study (Bolton, 1976
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: Xiphomyrmex severini Xiphomyrmex severini Emery , 1895
Citation.Name: Emery

Tetramorium quadrispinosum Tetramorium quadrispinosum Emery

Citation.Paragraph:
Of the introduced forms it has always been accepted that
Tetramorium simillimum simillimum ,
Tetramorium pacificum pacificum and
Tetramorium bicarinatum bicarinatum (this last referred to in earlier literature as
Tetramorium guineense guineense ; see Bolton, 1977
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: were introduced in the past (M. R. Smith, 1943
Citation.Name: M. R. Smith

Citation.Paragraph: Creighton, 1950
Citation.Name: Creighton

Citation.Paragraph: Brown, 1957
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph: and more recently Brown (1964
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph:
a) has proved that a similar origin is definite for
Tetramorium lucayanum lucayanum . There was some controversy over the status of
Tetramorium caespitum caespitum , with Smith (1943
Citation.Name: Smith

Citation.Paragraph: believing the species to be introduced and Creighton (1950
Citation.Name: Creighton

Citation.Paragraph: maintaining that it was endemic. Brown (1957
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph:
set out the argument for
Tetramorium caespitum caespitum being an introduced form and on the whole I agree with his conclusions. In the same paper Brown also pointed out that debate over the origins of
Tetramorium rugiventris T. rugiventris was misplaced as the species belonged in fact to genus
Myrmica Myrmica (but see Gregg, 1961
Citation.Name: Gregg

Citation.Paragraph:
The present survey has shown that seven introduced
Tetramorium Tetramorium species are present in the New World fauna, rather than five as implied in the latest previous estimate (Brown, 1964
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph: Turning to the endemic forms, all of which belong to the spinosum-complex of the tortuosumgroup, there seems to have been tacit agreement in all the above-mentioned publications, and in the first part of the present survey (Bolton, 1976
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
that only a single species was present,
Tetramorium spinosum spinosum , represented by four subspecies in the more arid zones of southern U. S. A. and Mexico. These forms were reviewed and redescribed by M. R. Smith (1938
Citation.Name: M. R. Smith

Citation.Paragraph: and his key was reproduced later by Creighton (1950
Citation.Name: Creighton

Citation.Paragraph: Here the situation rested until the constituents were reviewed by M. R. Smith (1938
Citation.Name: M. R. Smith

Citation.Paragraph:
who regarded the complex as consisting of a single species with four subspecies corresponding to the names
Xiphomyrmex spinosus spinosus ,
Xiphomyrmex spinosus hispidus hispidus ,
Xiphomyrmex spinosus insons insons ,
Tetramorium wheeleri wheeleri . However, he pointed out that ' the subspecies of
Xiphomyrmex spinosus spinosus represent extreme variations, and that there are other forms intermediate between the named forms. The existence of these intermediates might justify the synonymizing of the subspecies with the typical form'. Despite this statement the taxonomic system put forward by Smith was reproduced by Creighton (1950
Citation.Name: Creighton

Citation.Paragraph: The chief objection to Smith's (1938
Citation.Name: Smith's

Citation.Paragraph: Very few samples from different localities need be examined to show that this character is very variable, and Creighton (1950
Citation.Name: Creighton

Citation.Name: Wheeler

Citation.Name: Wheeler

Citation.Paragraph:
One species of the group,
Tetramorium bicarinatum bicarinatum , is a highly successful tramp-species and has been recorded from all over the world except for the Ethiopian region. Two other members of the group have some tramping ability,
Tetramorium insolens insolens and
Tetramorium pacificum pacificum . The former closely resembles
Tetramorium bicarinatum bicarinatum and has been found to date in Britain, Germany and the U. S. A., but always as an introduction or living in zoological or botanical gardens. The latter occurs sporadically in California where it has been recorded by M. R. Smith (1943
Citation.Name: M. R. Smith

Citation.Paragraph: and Creighton (1950
Citation.Name: Creighton

Citation.Paragraph:
types lost).
Tetramorium bicarinatum Tetramorium bicarinatum (Nylander) ; Mayr, 1862
Citation.Name: Mayr

Citation.Paragraph:
740. [For a full statement of the current synonymy of
Tetramorium bicarinatum bicarinatum , application of the name and discussion of the species see Bolton, 1977
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Name: F. Smith

Citation.Name: F. Smith) ; Donisthorpe

The differences between this species and the closely related
Tetramorium bicarinatum bicarinatum were tabulated in part 2 (Bolton, 1977
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
As a tramp-species
Tetramorium insolens insolens is by no means as successful as
Tetramorium bicarinatum bicarinatum . It has a very wide range in the Pacific island-systems and is known from Indonesia, Philippines and the Solomon Islands. It was collected by E. O. Wilson in Sri Lanka, where it may be an introduction, and in England (in orchid house), Germany (zoological garden) and in the U. S. A. (near Los Angeles) where it is most certainly introduced. The Los Angeles specimens are deposited in USNM, Washington; for other localities see Bolton (1977
Citation.Name: Bolton

This is the dominant and only endemic group of
Tetramorium Tetramorium in the Palaearctic region. One species,
Tetramorium caespitum caespitum , has been introduced into North America (M. R. Smith, 1943
Citation.Name: M. R. Smith

Citation.Paragraph: Brown, 1957
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph: and it is now well established in the U. S. A. with a wide range on that continent (Creighton, 1950

Citation.Paragraph:
The camerunense-group is based upon West and Central Africa, where about 13 species are known. One species of the group,
Tetramorium lucayanum lucayanum , was described from the Bahamas and Brown (1957
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph: voiced the opinion that the species was probably of African origin. Later Brown (1964
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph: At present the known New World distribution includes Cuba, Puerto Rico, Jamaica, Virgin Islands and Bahamas (type-locality) as recorded by Brown (1964
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph:
As far as is known
Tetramorium melanogyna melanogyna is restricted to the Solomon Islands and thus it is only specimens from here which may be confused with
Tetramorium insolens insolens , which also occurs on these islands. Samples of
Tetramorium melanogyna melanogyna workers will key out at
Tetramorium insolens insolens in Bolton (1977
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
The queens of the two species are easily distinguished as in
Tetramorium insolens insolens the female has the same colouring as the workers, whilst in
Tetramorium melanogyna melanogyna the queen is uniform dark brown. Other names given as synonyms of
Tetramorium insolens insolens in Bolton (1977
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:

Tetramorium vertigum vertigum Bolton of Sulawesi and running to that species in the key (Bolton, 1977
Citation.Name: Bolton

Wilson) at present housed in MCZ, Cambridge and referred previously (Bolton, 1977
